document.title: South Carolina College- and Career-Ready Standards for Mathematics

FFC59F29854D4AFBAD3D8300988F183A.description: Compare theoretical and experimental probabilities for compound events.

7C8E8DAC6D914839B982CF315A0441CA.description: Design and use simulations to collect data and determine probabilities.

C7E21F7D57B846C79F0E4FD2A3E3B354.description:
Determine probabilities of compound events using organized lists, tables, and
tree diagrams.

C0E88D5DDB43485A88AA7BD4DDCFE5A3.description:
Identify the outcomes in a sample space using organized lists, tables, and tree
diagrams.

9299BD1D6479445C87249313F7AC50A9.description: Understand that the probability of a compound event is between 0 and 1.

55B9DA8BB6B64599A692530B243FC396.description: Extend the concepts of simple events to investigate compound events.¬†

91D9A9367F4742C6BCF4EA7B478E8C21.description: Perform experiments to test the validity of probability models.

8DFC9E9837E6475F96E4D4AD1B58D1B7.description: Develop both uniform and non-uniform probability models.

A074E3D4C1FF48FA84956436CC91E876.description:
Differentiate between uniform and non-uniform probability models
(distributions).

C2FC7D59D2D548DBB07720230224349C.description: Apply the concepts of theoretical and experimental probabilities for simple events.

3A928096F8DD44D38F37595E4AA29B12.description: Perform experiments that model theoretical probability.¬†

C923E26A502B46E19DAFF28241F2ADD1.description: Determine approximate outcomes using theoretical probability.¬†

8741AA68573342E3BA979E843954A0CE.description:
Investigate the relationship between theoretical and experimental probabilities for
 simple events.¬†

C99D606B5E0D48EB9CE2946E00072252.description: Understand that a probability closer to 0 indicates an unlikely chance event.

F3669C4F034B45FAAB1B07A4171CE0B7.description:
Understand that a probability close to 1/2
indicates that a chance event is neither
likely nor unlikely

422791F9460C46EB8B7756F7338E873A.description: Understand that a probability closer to 1 indicates a likely chance event.

FE96A37999EE488AB05CCCC2CD4D30F8.description: Understand that the probability of a chance event is a number between 0 and 1.

22D0F7E77F01400C824F18AB3DDB2E9F.description: Understand that probability measures likelihood of a chance event occurring.

6626B296A10240A0A2CBADD192D87C1F.description: Investigate the concept of probability of chance events.¬†

A20ABA3551EF4E668C13B8D61885407D.description:
Compare the numerical measures of center (mean, median, mode) and variability
 (range, interquartile range, mean absolute deviation) from two random samples to
draw inferences about the populations.¬†

147B16413E374B7D97791F9E4A366C3D.description:
Visually compare the centers, spreads, and overlap of two displays of data (i.e., dot
plots, histograms, box plots) that are graphed on the same scale and draw inferences
about this data.¬†

05E2E5A1C7C74918884D3840AB79E59F.description:
Draw inferences about a population by collecting multiple random samples of the
 same size to investigate variability in estimates of the characteristic of interest.¬†

077F63A4F3904E759FFD8276AF105121.description:
Understand that random sampling is used to gather a representative sample and
supports valid inferences about the population.

B808879E091841AB9F46B82366373540.description:
Understand that generalizations from a sample are valid only if the sample is
representative of the population.

129A147DEFEA4300973ABF11632FCBB2.description: Differentiate between random and non-random sampling.

D214C873835143F2892D15ECE695F1FC.description:
Understand that a sample is a subset of a population and both possess the same
characteristics.

577F528799EB40CA8A09EE6D47D43D2C.description: Use the formulas for area, volume, and surface area appropriately

551D382C609E482A95E344DBA99A5799.description:
Decompose cubes, right rectangular prisms, and right triangular prisms into
rectangles and triangles to derive the formulas for volume and surface area.

7FBF3EB150FC4888B8C062F81C5F8CC5.description:
Understand that the concepts of volume and surface area are applied to three-dimensional figures such as cubes, right rectangular prisms, and right triangular
prisms.

B8BFEF03318342BCA2B1212337A19682.description:
Understand that the concept of area is applied to two-dimensional figures such as
triangles, quadrilaterals, and polygons.

9ED1DC8D62524C968AC2FD1A2637B9FA.description:
Apply the concepts of two- and three-dimensional figures to real-world and
mathematical situations.¬†

6790D7055302444FB577728730284BAD.description:
Write equations to solve problems involving the relationships between angles formed
by two intersecting lines, including supplementary, complementary, vertical, and
adjacent.¬†

58A4ED9A4E39408F86E8EF68458793AB.description:
Use the formulas for circumference and area of circles appropriately to solve
real-world and mathematical problems.

134A501778284852B626859A3F4FC2D6.description: Explore the relationship between circumference and area using a visual model.

ECCF4FA4E8E346FEAF8C4246C3163E77.description:
Understand that the constant of proportionality between the circumference and
diameter is equivalent to ÔÅ∞

8775DA602E2C452EACDEEB50FC44E4E8.description:
Demonstrate an understanding of the proportional relationships between
diameter, radius, and circumference of a circle.

5C70BEB86A70486D86E1A221E1677E65.description:
Describe two-dimensional cross-sections of three-dimensional figures, specifically
right rectangular prisms and right rectangular pyramids.¬†

3DB8C40C54AD495FB6D43DE22DA2FE60.description:
Construct special quadrilaterals (i.e., kite, trapezoid, isosceles trapezoid,
rhombus, parallelogram, rectangle) given specific parameters about angles or
sides.

020971486466491C8F60B516D4C9730C.description:
Decide if the measurements determine a unique triangle, more than one triangle,
or no triangle.

7EFACE2450C9428198CF1AFEF0C5C813.description: Construct triangles given all measurements of either angles or sides.

4829A69B25C54F17A63BC357A94F08E3.description:
Construct triangles and special quadrilaterals using a variety of tools (e.g., freehand,
ruler and protractor, technology).¬†

CBF96DE1C304499B806F61C5CC37CB1F.description:
¬†Determine the scale factor and translate between scale models and actual
measurements (e.g., lengths, area) of real-world objects and geometric figures using
proportional reasoning.¬†

2ECAE5E813324972AB6DF4295161F5BC.description:
Understand and apply the laws of exponents (i.e., product rule, quotient rule, power to
a power, product to a power, quotient to a power, zero power property) to simplify
numerical expressions that include whole-number exponents.

03C9F51501CB45139B732F8B361D3460.description:
Identify and justify the steps for solving multi-step linear equations and two-step
linear inequalities.

598247BE47CA447199E7D98E84F30A7F.description:
Write and solve two-step linear inequalities. Graph the solution set on a number
line and interpret its meaning.

18DB0CBFBC7A4BDFA56D115BEEB06AB4.description:
Write and solve multi-step linear equations that include the use of the distributive
property and combining like terms. Exclude equations that contain variables on
both sides.

6FBD4FB0EB444630A004DE8C8A5E8FBA.description:
Write and fluently solve linear equations of the form ùëéùë• + ùëè = ùëê and
ùëé(ùë• + ùëè) = ùëê where ùëé, ùëè, and ùëê are rational numbers.

0CE8BC4CF07C425EA187C9D976193B02.description:
Apply the concepts of linear equations and inequalities in one variable to real-world
and mathematical situations

3AE512381AEE487C8DAD6C4B1F626ECF.description:
Extend previous understanding of Order of Operations to solve multi-step real-world
and mathematical problems involving rational numbers. Include fraction bars as a
grouping symbol.

68A7510F15A4452A9463D955DB8DFDB1.description:
Recognize that algebraic expressions may have a variety of equivalent forms and
determine an appropriate form for a given real-world situation.¬†

B5DA496AE43F41B1945D2213CAC9103C.description:
Apply mathematical properties (e.g., commutative, associative, distributive) to simplify
and to factor linear algebraic expressions with rational coefficients.

39BBFB127699435C9FED4CC8DA607825.description:
Solve real-world and mathematical problems involving ratios and percentages using
proportional reasoning (e.g., multi-step dimensional analysis, percent
increase/decrease, tax).¬†

212ACB5F65A743028E10836BBDECF8EE.description:
Investigate the graph of a proportional relationship and explain the meaning of
specific points (e.g., origin, unit rate) in the context of the situation.

33ADED844699457FA8537F351ACD3A47.description: Use equations to model proportional relationships.

9BC21BEF2A134B36AC73384B8119EA20.description: Understand that the constant of proportionality is the unit rate.

520DA9DA1E96428C82147C07C2CA6AA0.description: Recognize or compute the constant of proportionality.

D04387398DDF4D26A6F8921791B3903D.description: Determine when two quantities are in a proportional relationship.¬†

3A810A6BC9CD4DFF961E509D8B918CCF.description:
Identify and model proportional relationships given multiple representations, including
tables, graphs, equations, diagrams, verbal descriptions, and real-world situations.¬†

0198427B06F3406D954944D506F6B022.description:
Compute unit rates, including those involving complex fractions, with like or different
units.¬†

BECC11F95FB5490AB61C9AF65F7F7A4D.description:
Extend prior knowledge to translate among multiple representations of rational
numbers (fractions, decimal numbers, percentages). Exclude the conversion of
repeating decimal numbers to fractions.

EB67AD107AE945AA87DF5F73227C13E6.description:
Use concepts of equality and inequality to write and explain real-world and
mathematical situations.

99D2981068C5463CBDC59A45083F252C.description:
Interpret statements using less than (<), greater than (>), less than or equal to (‚â§),
greater than or equal to (‚â•), and equal to (=) as relative locations on the number
line.

445CB6B153B3439FA35F85E88F3DB7C6.description: Understand and apply the concepts of comparing and ordering to rational numbers

1AF457ACD45247BDAE39577FF60DC517.description:
Apply the concepts of all four operations with rational numbers to solve real-world and
mathematical problems.¬†

901EF23DB7994BD7B94E3BB90EE89A3B.description:
Understand that some rational numbers can be written as integers and all rational
numbers can be written as fractions or decimal numbers that terminate or repeat.

658DC3913C28498B9443CE1F85F64DDB.description:
Apply mathematical properties (e.g., commutative, associative, distributive, or
the properties of identity and inverse elements) to multiply and divide rational
numbers.

84E58442E1704ADF813A9F99C3E513A0.description:
Understand sign rules for dividing rational numbers and that a quotient of
integers (with a non-zero divisor) is a rational number.

2734005F86CE4A3098FF819D5CA80D8E.description: Understand sign rules for multiplying rational numbers.

DFF3523124654AE3AFF6457AFF956AF6.description:
Understand that the multiplicative inverse of a number is its reciprocal and their
product is equal to one.

DC253B1A68534AC29DA5F2F0F057A9B8.description:
Extend prior knowledge of operations with positive rational numbers to multiply and to
divide all rational numbers.

8C66AA143C614918AAC938A015173841.description:
Apply mathematical properties (e.g., commutative, associative, distributive, or
the properties of identity and inverse elements) to add and subtract rational
numbers.

90FB30E61DA34ADFB2E99F6EEF72F8D8.description:
Demonstrate that the distance between two rational numbers on the number line
is the absolute value of their difference.

DE70249133784617AF720959C71654E6.description:
Translate between the subtraction of rational numbers and addition using the
additive inverse, ùëù ‚àí ùëû = ùëù + (‚àíùëû).

8F5501865CD2462E8CD7C427690D0C15.description:
Understand that the sum of two rational numbers (ùëù + ùëû) represents a distance
from p on the number line equal to |q| where the direction is indicated by the sign
of q.

03D9B1A3348F4454A3D55DBA3B475D80.description:
Understand that the additive inverse of a number is its opposite and their sum is
equal to zero.

2D1AFC8C94234B178FA12BC0241AA28E.description:
Extend prior knowledge of operations with positive rational numbers to add and to
subtract all rational numbers and represent the sum or difference on a number line.
